Dear mlpack developers, the OpenCV Machine Learning Library [1] is another location where C++ implementations of machine learning methods are collected. How do you position yourself with respect to that library? E.g., [2] gives the impression that you are not going to wrap 3rd party methods, like libsvm (as OpenCV does). Is this correct? Best regards, Robert [1] http://docs.opencv.org/modules/ml/doc/ml.html [2] http://trac.research.cc.gatech.edu/fastlab/ticket/122 _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack Hello, is there an archive of this mailing list? The one on https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/pipermail/mlpack/ is empty. Btw., I can recommend setting one up at http://gmane.org/. I found their search functionality useful, and one can also import a local (mbox) archive to initialize it. Robert _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On Mon, Mar 11, 2013 at 04:17:14PM +0100, Jaelon wrote: > Dear Ryan, > > First of all I want to thank you for the fast response. > It kind of figured that I could just use double with a simple type > conversion, but was unsure about the influence on the results. > > However I am still left with the question what to do with the > "vector > states;". > Is this the amount of values in one sequence of observed values or > is it the amount of possible states that it can be, or maybe even > something else entirely? > > In my case I get my data from video samples and the amount of values > for one video sample vary. I have already changed my code a bit so > that the values per sample are stored in a different column of the > "vector >", meaning that each column contains a > sequence of values for one video sample and the amount of rows is > equal to the amount of video samples used. I hope this is the way it > is supposed to be done, as I have no way of testing it until the my > problem with states is fixed. Ah! Sorry, I forgot to answer that question. The states vector (vector >) are the states which correspond to each observation (the observations vector, vector >). When you train the HMM with Train(), it is training with labeled data. So for each observation, you need to pass the corresponding label. That is, states[i] is the index of the hidden state corresponding with observations[i]. In the example you gave, you were only using one hidden state, so the states vector should be entirely filled with zeroes, and be the same length as the observations vector. Thank you for pointing out these issues. Sometimes, when writing documentation, it is hard to know what people will find confusing. -- Ryan Curtin | "So I got that going for me, which is nice." ryan@igglybob.com | - Carl Spackler _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack (missed reply-all a second ago) That patch is somewhat similar to a mod I tried. _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack Dear Mrs, Sir, I have only recently begun learning about machine learning and more specific about hidden markov models as I need to use these. I have a project in C++ and the mlpack library seemed like the best option to use for training and using HMM. However I find the documentation about HMM somewhat vague on not entirely clear. There is a piece of example code there but that doesn't work for me. Here is an overview of what I need to do: I have a program that throws me data on which i need to train the HMM. The data contains discrete as well as continuous data. The data can vary between 4 and 27 variables being integers, floats and vector. If I am correct these are my observations as I know what these stand for and can extract them with ease. But I don't need to use all of the different variables at once as I want to look at the performance when using every one of them on its own and then expanding it to take more variables into account. For now I want to look at the first variable. This is a sequence of integer values ranging from 0 to 5 (thus discrete), these values are stored in a vector . So here is what i try to do: /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// vector > handvector; arma::Mat handobservations; vector > states; int hidden_states = 1; //leaving this on 1 for now hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, distribution::DiscreteDistribution()); for(uint i = 0; i that is created earlier in the code { handobservations << hands[i] << arma::endr; handvector.push_back(handobservations); handobservations.clear(); } handhmm.Train(handvector, states); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Now the problem with this is the Train member function won't accept vector >, it only seems to accept vector >. Also states is left empty for this and that isn't accepted either. So what needs to be put in states and is there a way to make train work with vector >? Any help or a more extended example than in the doc will be greatly appreciated. With kind regards, Joery _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On Tue, Apr 09, 2013 at 12:37:22PM +0800, zhijie he wrote: > Hi, > > I am Zhijie He, a master candidate at National University of Singapore. My > research interest is natural language processing and machine learning. I > will gradate this May, so I have a lot of time to do the GSoC project. > > I am interested in developing a collaborative filtering package for mlpack. > I was wondering before submit my application, do I have to do some other > things like submit a patch for mlpack? Do you have other requirements for > the applicants? Hello Zhijie (and Salman who had nearly the same question), The collaborative filtering project is as much of a research project as it is an implementation project. As the description says, the project entails researching what the state-of-the-art is in CF and implementing it, with an emphasis on scalability. It is a somewhat open-ended project, so a good application for that project should already have CF domain knowledge and ideas for what exactly could be implemented. You are welcome to submit patches to mlpack if you find bugs, but that is not necessary for a GSoC application. Hopefully this information is helpful. Thanks, Ryan -- Ryan Curtin | "I am the luckiest man alive!" ryan@igglybob.com | - General Borzov _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On 03/11/2013 03:41 PM, Ryan Curtin wrote: > On Mon, Mar 11, 2013 at 11:10:56AM +0100, Jaelon wrote: >> Dear Mrs, Sir, >> >> I have only recently begun learning about machine learning and more >> specific about hidden markov models as I need to use these. >> I have a project in C++ and the mlpack library seemed like the best >> option to use for training and using HMM. However I find the >> documentation about HMM somewhat vague on not entirely clear. >> There is a piece of example code there but that doesn't work for me. >> >> Here is an overview of what I need to do: >> I have a program that throws me data on which i need to train the >> HMM. The data contains discrete as well as continuous data. The data >> can vary between 4 and 27 variables being integers, floats and >> vector. If I am correct these are my observations as I know >> what these stand for and can extract them with ease. >> But I don't need to use all of the different variables at once as I >> want to look at the performance when using every one of them on its >> own and then expanding it to take more variables into account. >> For now I want to look at the first variable. >> This is a sequence of integer values ranging from 0 to 5 (thus >> discrete), these values are stored in a vector . So here is >> what i try to do: >> >> /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// >> vector > handvector; >> arma::Mat handobservations; >> vector > states; >> int hidden_states = 1; //leaving this on 1 for now >> >> hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, >> distribution::DiscreteDistribution()); >> for(uint i = 0; i >> that is created earlier in the code >> { >> handobservations << hands[i] << arma::endr; >> handvector.push_back(handobservations); >> handobservations.clear(); >> } >> >> handhmm.Train(handvector, states); >> ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// >> >> Now the problem with this is the Train member function won't accept >> vector >, it only seems to accept >> vector >. >> Also states is left empty for this and that isn't accepted either. >> So what needs to be put in states and is there a way to make train >> work with vector >? >> >> Any help or a more extended example than in the doc will be greatly >> appreciated. > Hello Joery, > > The Train() function accepts vector > regardless of > the distribution type. For the discrete distribution, casting the > integers to doubles should work, but this is not an optimal solution: > > arma::Mat handobservations; > for (uint i = 0; i < hands.size(); i++) > { > handobservations << (double) hands[i] << arma::endr; > handvector.push_back(handobservations); > handobservations.clear(); > } > > In the coming days I will refactor the HMM class so that for > DiscreteDistribution, arma::Mat will be accepted (as it should be). > This will be slightly involved because it means each distribution type > will have to define its own observation type (arma::Mat for > DiscreteDistribution, arma::Mat for GaussianDistribution, and so > forth). > > I will also write more complete documentation and a tutorial for HMMs, > and then I'll let you know when that is all done. In the mean time, the > fix I proposed above should work. If it doesn't, or you have any other > questions, let me know. Dear Ryan, First of all I want to thank you for the fast response. It kind of figured that I could just use double with a simple type conversion, but was unsure about the influence on the results. However I am still left with the question what to do with the "vector > states;". Is this the amount of values in one sequence of observed values or is it the amount of possible states that it can be, or maybe even something else entirely? In my case I get my data from video samples and the amount of values for one video sample vary. I have already changed my code a bit so that the values per sample are stored in a different column of the "vector >", meaning that each column contains a sequence of values for one video sample and the amount of rows is equal to the amount of video samples used. I hope this is the way it is supposed to be done, as I have no way of testing it until the my problem with states is fixed. _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On Tue, Apr 09, 2013 at 09:04:59PM -0600, Daniel Bell wrote: > oh ok thank you, I guess at my current level it is just outside my > reach. I am in my first algorithm course. could you recommend > something similar that might be more in my current skill set? If you are deadset on doing statistical machine learning implementation and none of the other less machine-learning-y projects are appealing to you, I suggest that your best bet is learning C++ and a fairly simple machine learning method (maybe decision trees of some sort -- which are different than the dual-tree algorithms I mentioned earlier; or maybe some rather simple nonlinear dimensionality reduction method such as IsoMap or LLE). Keep in mind that mlpack is looking for fast algorithms, so the off-the-shelf IsoMap algorithm (for example) may not be as asymptotically fast as some more recently published improvement on the algorithm (in the case of IsoMap I am not certain if one exists). -- Ryan Curtin | "I'm going to be on television!" ryan@igglybob.com | - Sara Goldfarb _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack Hi All- I'm trying to use mlpack's GMM with some data I've got. I'm not so familiar with the statistical tools used here as I should be, so I've run into some problems that I'm having trouble debugging on my own: - First, I often get "error: inv(): matrix appears to be singular" during estimation. It appears that during estimation, one (or more) rows and columns of a covariance matrix become 0, and I think this causes it to become non-invertible. - Second, in cases when estimation completes, I often end up with means, weights and covariances which are all -nan. I'm not sure whether I'm mis-using the tool or I've got funny data which need to be conditioned. It's six-dimensional, values less than 1.0 and one of the features is very often zero. (I'm wondering if that last bit means that one good gaussian would be zero mean and zero stdev, resulting in a degenerate covariance matrix -- though I don't know enough stat and linear algebra to work this out.) Can someone give some advice? I've posted a small sub-set of my data which can trigger these problems: www.cs.columbia.edu/~jdd/gmm_obs0.csv If I run "./gmm -i gmm_obs0.csv -g 5" I can get the first problem. Changing the number of gaussians to 8 results in the second problem. Thanks in advance, John

However it is still > giving me the same error. > Now I have tried to get it working with a simple piece of hardcoded > data as follows: > > vector > handvector; > arma::Mat observations; > int hidden_states = 5; > size_t observ_dimension; > vector emissions; > arma::mat transitions; > > observations << 5 << 4 << 5 << 5 << arma::endr; > observations << 2 << 1 << 1 << 2 << arma::endr; > handvector.push_back(observations); > > hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, > distribution::DiscreteDistribution(observations.n_rows)); > > printf("Ready for training\n"); > handhmm.Train(handvector); //the error comes from calling training > when looking at my output > printf("Done training model\n"); > observ_dimension = handhmm.Dimensionality(); > printf("Retrieved dimensionality\n"); > emissions = handhmm.Emission(); > printf("Retrieved emission matrix\n"); > transitions = handhmm.Transition(); > printf("Retrieved transition matrix"); > > As you see I used 4 columns with 2 datapoints for each observation > while using only one sequence. > This is a very simple example that is a fictional representation of > what I put into the observations (when I would use 1 video with a very > small amount of extracted data). > I initialize the hmm (handhmm) with 5 hidden states (this is just a > random number I chose as the number of hidden states will be unknown in > the real case) and a discrete distribution for 2 observations. > > Maybe this example can clarify what I am doing and give you insight in > what I might be doing wrong. > It think it might also be helpful to others to have such an example in > the documentation. > > With kind regards, > Joery Sorry for the slow reply; things have been busy for me. The problem is here: > hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, > distribution::DiscreteDistribution(observations.n_rows)); The constructor of DiscreteDistribution is defined as (from core/dists/discrete_distribution.hpp): > /** > * Define the discrete distribution as having numObservations possible > * observations. The probability in each state will be set to (1 / > * numObservations). > * > * @param numObservations Number of possible observations this > * distribution > * can have. > */ > DiscreteDistribution(const size_t numObservations); You are giving observations.n_rows, which is the dimensionality of the observations, and not the number of possible observations. Your observations vector contains observation '5', while DiscreteDistribution() only expects to see one observation. To correct this, the constructor parameter to DiscreteDistribution() should be one greater than the highest-numbered state that is observed (because 0 is also a valid state): > hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, > distribution::DiscreteDistribution(6)); I have modified DiscreteDistribution to provide much better error output when compiled with debugging symbols (-DDEBUG). With this change your example code gives: ---- Ready for training [DEBUG] DiscreteDistribution::Probability(): received observation 2; observation must be in [0, 1] for this distribution. error: Mat::operator(): out of bounds terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::logic_error' what(): Aborted ---- > Edit: I have also figured out that > observations << 5 << 4 << 5 << 5 << arma::endr; > observations << 2 << 1 << 1 << 2 << arma::endr; > writes to the first row 2 times so I changed that to > observations << 5 << 4 << 5 << 5 << arma::endr << 2 << 1 << 1 << 2 << > arma::endr; > However that doesn't fix the problem (only brought to my intention that > it is better to just initialize the arma::mat with a given size and > then setting the elements individually). This is true, but be aware that the DiscreteDistribution class currently only supports single-dimensional observations. If you have multi-dimensional discrete data, you could convert it into one-dimensional data kind of like this: state (0, 0) --> state 0 state (0, 1) --> state 1 state (0, 2) --> state 2 state (1, 0) --> state 3 state (1, 1) --> state 4 state (1, 2) --> state 5 I hope this information is helpful, and again, sorry for the slow response. -- Ryan Curtin | "For more enjoyment and greater efficiency, ryan@igglybob.com | consumption is being standardized." _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack Hey, I am currently working with GMM and it worked for two models with decent results up to now. However when attempting to train for a third model I get mean, covariance and transmission matrices filled with NaN. My input data has 15 dimensions consisting of values that range between 0 and 4. My guess is that excessive appearance of the value zero is causing the problem and thus I tried adding a very small value to every datapoint, but this did not solve the problem. I am training 7 models with data like explained above. 2 of them always give me NaN matrices and take way longer to train so something is going wrong with the training. Could you give me an possible reason for this problem and/or point me in the direction to solving this, I have been stuck several hours on this now). PS. I updated from the repository about 6hours ago (version r14885) With many thanks, Joery _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On 03/19/2013 07:56 PM, Ryan Curtin wrote: > On Fri, Mar 15, 2013 at 01:14:29PM +0100, Jaelon wrote: >> Me again, >> >> I now understand how the observations are supposed to be filled in and >> changed that in my code. >> As you mentioned I just needed a transpose of the arma::mat matrices to >> have the observation vector filled in correctly. things have been busy for me. > > The problem is here: > >> hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, >> distribution::DiscreteDistribution(observations.n_rows)); > The constructor of DiscreteDistribution is defined as (from > core/dists/discrete_distribution.hpp): > >> /** >> * Define the discrete distribution as having numObservations possible >> * observations. The probability in each state will be set to (1 / >> * numObservations). >> * >> * @param numObservations Number of possible observations this >> * distribution >> * can have. >> */ >> DiscreteDistribution(const size_t numObservations); > You are giving observations.n_rows, which is the dimensionality of the > observations, and not the number of possible observations. Your > observations vector contains observation '5', while > DiscreteDistribution() only expects to see one observation. > > To correct this, the constructor parameter to DiscreteDistribution() > should be one greater than the highest-numbered state that is observed > (because 0 is also a valid state): > >> hmm::HMM handhmm(hidden_states, >> distribution::DiscreteDistribution(6)); > I have modified DiscreteDistribution to provide much better error output > when compiled with debugging symbols (-DDEBUG). With this change your > example code gives: > > ---- > Ready for training > [DEBUG] DiscreteDistribution::Probability(): received observation 2; > observation must be in [0, 1] for this distribution. > > error: Mat::operator(): out of bounds > > terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::logic_error' > what(): > Aborted > ---- > >> Edit: I have also figured out that >> observations << 5 << 4 << 5 << 5 << arma::endr; >> observations << 2 << 1 << 1 << 2 << arma::endr; >> writes to the first row 2 times so I changed that to >> observations << 5 << 4 << 5 << 5 << arma::endr << 2 << 1 << 1 << 2 << >> arma::endr; >> However that doesn't fix the problem (only brought to my intention that >> it is better to just initialize the arma::mat with a given size and >> then setting the elements individually). > This is true, but be aware that the DiscreteDistribution class currently > only supports single-dimensional observations. If you have > multi-dimensional discrete data, you could convert it into > one-dimensional data kind of like this: > > state (0, 0) --> state 0 > state (0, 1) --> state 1 > state (0, 2) --> state 2 > state (1, 0) --> state 3 > state (1, 1) --> state 4 > state (1, 2) --> state 5 > > I hope this information is helpful, and again, sorry for the slow > response. > Thx for the feedback, it explains and clarifies a lot to me. I have been digging into the code myself and wondered about the dimensionality that is hardcoded on 1 and also about the possibility to make one observation value of the vectors I have for each observation, I also started to implement the hmm algorithms myself today. However due to your answer I don't think there is any need to continue with my own implementation, for which I am thankful as well :p . I can get the simple example running now and will try to do some more advanced test tomorrow. One more question now though: Is the download on the website the one with the updated Distribution code, as it states "released februari 8" Again many thanks, Joery On Tue, Apr 09, 2013 at 09:27:42PM +0530, Pramanshu Rajput wrote: > I am an undergraduate student at Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, > India > > I want to know about the possibility of project on adding new features to > mlpack including Restricted Boltzmann Machines and some Genetic Algorithms > ranging from very basic like Simulated Annealing, (Mu,Lambda) Evolution > Strategy to some of the more advanced algorithms. Genetic algorithms are entertainingly slow, so I am not sure how useful they are in the context of mlpack, which aims to be a fast library. Also, simulated annealing and genetic algorithms are not the same thing, but they are both global optimization strategies (in some sense). You are not restricted to only the ideas in the Ideas List (as it says on that page), but if you are considering doing some other project, you will have to detail it in your proposal. Your proposal will have to convince us that your idea is a fast algorithm that can be implemented without additional library dependencies, that you know the algorithm inside-out and can implement it efficiently, other implementations that you seek to outperform, and then how it will fit into the existing mlpack codebase (both from the perspective of code cleanliness and also the bigger picture of how all mlpack algorithms fit together). Hopefully this is helpful. I am interested in learning about and learning > machine learning however I have never programmed in C++. Do you think > this is within my skill set that I have laid out? The tree traversal project is a particularly difficult one which expects rigorous C++ knowledge. This does not mean that you could not do it, but in slightly more detail: Many of the algorithms in mlpack are fast because they are tree-based branch-and-bound algorithms. If you don't know about those you can read them about them online; search for something like 'nearest neighbor' and 'kd-trees'. In addition, there are many different possible types of trees and many different machine learning algorithms. mlpack uses C++ templates to provide abstract traversals and algorithms which can work with any type of tree (assuming the user implements the tree with the proper methods). This is actually very neat and to my knowledge there is no other library which implements anything even remotely similar. However, the functionality is still somewhat experimental -- which is why the tree abstractions haven't been advertised as a main selling point. The branch and bound type algorithms to which I was referring to earlier depend heavily on tight bounds. So improving the effectiveness of these tree traversals will depend on the implementation of the bounds in the algorithms and the efficiency of those bound calculations (as well as other calculations). So the project would involve both analyzing the existing traversals for either algorithmic or implementational improvements as well as examining the existing algorithms. I could talk about this all day, given that it is my primary research interest, but I'll spare the gory details for now. tl;dr: if you're a second-year undergraduate without heavy algorithmic knowledge and you're interested in this project, you probably are best served by putting in 30 hours a week reading papers both on dual-tree algorithms and learning C++ inside-out (metaprogramming does happen in the mlpack world of trees). So, I'm not going to say it's impossible, but there's a reason its difficulty is rated a 9/10... -- Ryan Curtin | "...I still don't know what it means." ryan@igglybob.com | - Rigby Reardon _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack oh ok thank you, I guess at my current level it is just outside my = reach. I am glad you find mlpack useful. > I have a question regarding mlpack::neighbor::NeighborSearch > > I am wondering if it is possible to perform a dynamic kNN search in > mlpack efficiently solving the all-NN problem repeatedly with a > changing point set S. > > As far as I know, all previously described methods handle only the > inserting and deleting of points between queries or the case of points > moving along a predetermined trajectories. This is different from the > dynamic problem I have in mind, wherein the points move slowly along > trajectories, but that these trajectories are not known in advance as > in the case of an optimization problem. > > The idea is that if the changes between point positions in subsequent > calls to the the mlpack::neighbor::AllkNN search algorithm are > sufficiently small, updating the tree should be faster than rebuilding > it from scratch. The mlpack algorithm would takes a S_i and a > corresponding tree T_i and update the tree to T_i+1 corresponding to a > new set of points S_i+1. A caveat is that the subsequent sets {S_i} and > {S_i+1} will, in general, contain an similar, but not exactly the same, > number of points. > > Any insight regarding this question would be most appreciated. I approached a problem like this once; at the end of each AllkNN search, we were finding an incremental transformation matrix and multiplying the points by that, then recalculating nearest neighbors. There are several ways to do this: (1) Instead of finding k nearest neighbors, find a * k nearest neighbors where a is some integer (I chose 10). Then apply the transformation matrix and do a brute-force search in the a * k nearest neighbors of each point. Every now and then, the tree gets fully rebuilt. This gives approximate solutions, though. This is what we chose to do. (2) For each point x in S_i, you have some corresponding point x' in S_{i + 1}. It seems like, in general, || x - x' || is small. Each BinarySpaceTree<> node has a corresponding HRectBound<>, which is the hyperrectangle bound that represents the enclosing hyperrectangle of all the points in the node. You could loop over each point in S_{i + 1}, find the BinarySpaceTree<> node it is a part of, and then expand the HRectBound associated with that node accordingly (using operator|=()). You'd also need to expand the HRectBounds of any parent nodes. This would mean your BinarySpaceTree is no longer a space partitioning tree -- the nodes would be overlapping. For AllkNN this is not a problem; it will still work, but it may affect the runtime adversely, especially as the bounding hyperrectangles become larger and larger. In the limit case you would get a tree with no discriminatory capabilities because all the bounding hyperrectangles are huge. (3) You could avoid modifying the hyperrectangles associated with each tree node by taking each point x' and finding which node it fits into, and placing it in that node (whereas x may have been in a different node). You could also split a node if it now has more points than the leafSize, and delete nodes when they have no points in them. I am not sure about the running time of this approach, but your tree would still be valid for any number of iterations and it would probably still run all-NN search quickly (as opposed to approach (2)). ---- Are these ideas helpful? I think I understood the problem. As long as you have some sort of valid tree structure with valid bounding rectangles, the NeighborSearch class will find the correct, exact nearest neighbors. -- Ryan Curtin | "Think! As far as I know, all previously described methods handle only the inserting and deleting of points between queries or the case of points moving along a predetermined trajectories. This is different from the dynamic problem I have in mind, wherein the points move slowly along trajectories, but that these trajectories are not known in advance as in the case of an optimization problem. The idea is that if the changes between point positions in subsequent calls to the the mlpack::neighbor::AllkNN search algorithm are sufficiently small, updating the tree should be faster than rebuilding it from scratch. The mlpack algorithm would takes a S_i and a corresponding tree T_i and update the tree to T_i+1 corresponding to a new set of points S_i+1. A caveat is that the subsequent sets {S_i} and {S_i+1} will, in general, contain an similar, but not exactly the same, number of points. Any insight regarding this question would be most appreciated. Audrius Stundzia

The issue was not that the entire covariance matrix was zero but instead that only one element on the diagonal was zero -- which makes it non-invertible. This could happen when the points for a particular cluster have no variance in one dimension (in your case, it was the fifth dimension). So instead of checking if the sum of the covariance diagonal is zero, now it checks each element and adds a perturbation accordingly. The perturbation is small (1e-50) so it does not affect the results of the phi() function to get the probability of a point. At the same time, it's large enough to make the matrix invertible. There are a number of other projects listed there which are not as difficult and that don't require such specific domain knowledge. Since you have no knowledge of the field, I highly suggest you consider one of the other ones. Nevertheless, here are some references that you could look into... ---- J.H. Friedman, J.L. Bentley, and R.A. Finkel. "An algorithm for finding best matches in logarithmic expected time." ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software (TOMS) 3.3 (1977): 209-226. J.L. Bentley and J.H. Friedman. "Data structures for range searching." ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR) 11.4 (1979): 397-409. K.L. Clarkson. "Nearest neighbor queries in metric spaces." Discrete & Computational Geometry 22.1 (1999): 63-93. A.W. Moore. "The Anchors Hierarchy: using the triangle inequality to survive high-dimensional data." Proceedings of the Sixteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (2000). A.G. Gray and A.W. Moore. "N-body problems in statistical learning." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (2001): 521-527. A.W. Moore. "Nonparametric density estimation: toward computational tractability." Proceedings of the Third SIAM International Conference on Data Mining (2003). A. Beygelzimer, S. Kakade, and J.L. Langford. "Cover trees for nearest neighbor." Proceedings of the 23rd International Conference on Machine Learning (2006). P. Ram, D. Lee, W.B. March, A.G. Gray. "Linear-time algorithms for pairwise statistical problems." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (2009). ---- I would not expect a first (or second) year undergraduate to be able to effectively tackle this project. The documentation here is somewhat unclear, and I will be fixing that
soon.  The type std::vector<arma::mat> is meant to hold a sequence of
data sequences.  I think you are saying that if you are using 5 videos,
each video is an individual arma::mat stored in the
std::vector<arma::mat>.  Then each point in the arma::mat should contain
one data point in each _column_ (not each row, which is what you wrote).

I suspect that if you transposed your data matrices, it would work.  In
addition to updating the documentation, I'll also add some runtime size
checks so that you'll get something more useful than "Mat::operator():
out of bounds".

The updated Distribution code is available from subversion, so you'll have to get it using svn: $ svn co http://svn.cc.gatech.edu/fastlab/mlpack/trunk/ mlpack The next mlpack release, which will probably be in a month or two, will include those changes, but for now, you can just use what's in the subversion repositories. -- Ryan Curtin | "I am a golden god!" ryan@igglybob.com | - Russell _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On Wed, Apr 10, 2013 at 08:49:12AM +0530, Siddharth wrote: > Hi, > > I am currently pursuing MS by Research in the field of image processing and > machine learning at IIIT- Hyderabad, India. I am interested in working for > mlpack this summer in a GSoC project. > > I propose to implement techniques for dimensionality reduction and metric > learning. > > http://homepage.tudelft.nl/19j49/Matlab_Toolbox_for_Dimensionality_Reduction.html > > I think this will be a good addition to mlpack. Which techniques are you planning to implement? Many of those nonlinear dimensionality techniques are slow. Instead what would be more interesting is a working implementation of MVU with LRSDP (see the end of the ideas list). There is no purpose in mlpack implementing a variety of methods poorly. Breadth is important but it cannot come at the cost of quality. If you are going to propose implementing all (or even some) (or more than one) of these methods, you will have to convince us that you can implement all of them effectively. And with tests. Proper unit tests are very important, and, testing machine learning methods for accuracy -- especially when most of the "tests" available are just reference implementations which could contain bugs -- is a rather difficult task which can take far longer than implementing the methods itself. Also, if you were planning to just wrap the MATLAB functions or "translate" them to C++, that's not acceptable. The implementation must be from the ground up and needs to be provably faster than any existing implementations to be accepted into the mlpack codebase (of course, you can't know that when you propose the project, but if you have papers which detail faster algorithms to implement, those are a good start). > There are also many kernel functions which have not been implemented. > > http://crsouza.blogspot.in/2010/03/kernel-functions-for-machine-learning.html I could implement these, fully with tests, in probably a day and a half. This could be an addendum onto an existing project but is too simple for someone with knowledge as advanced as yourself. Hopefully these are helpful answers. This is the ryan@igglybob.com | War Room!" - President Muffley _______________________________________________ mlpack mailing list mlpack@cc.gatech.edu https://mailman.cc.gatech.edu/mailman/listinfo/mlpack On Tue, Apr 09, 2013 at 03:58:06PM +0200, Robert Pollak wrote: > Dear mlpack developers, > > the OpenCV Machine Learning Library [1] is another location where C++ > implementations of machine learning methods are collected. How do you > position yourself with respect to that library? > > E.g., [2] gives the impression that you are not going to wrap 3rd party > methods, like libsvm (as OpenCV does). Is this correct? Hello Robert, OpenCV focuses on computer vision (hence the name) whereas mlpack focuses on large-scale statistical learning techniques. mlpack is more applicable to people who are either looking to try less standard machine learning algorithms (i.e. sparse coding, LARS, density estimation trees, etc.) or who are looking to modify our flexible algorithms for the purposes of their research. To that end, for instance, any user can write their own distance metric and plug it in to mlpack code (without any runtime penalty). You are right that we aren't very interested in wrapping other libraries (other than Armadillo). Some libraries -- especially scientific libraries (cough cough Boost.math) -- change APIs in unexpected ways and this makes maintenance an ugly proposition filled with #ifdefs and other hackery. Instead, our goal is to, at the machine learning method level, keep things in-house for the sake of maintainability. We'd love to have an SVM implementation someday, but there isn't too much point in producing one if it can't outperform libsvm (if it can't, there's not too much motivation to use our implementation). Does this clarify things? If not, let me know.
